description:
As of 27 October the Zimbabwe curfew times will start at 22:00 to 06:00.  The minister of information noted “the Cabinet wishes to inform the public that border operating hours are being fixed between 0600 and 1800 hours until further assessment of the situation. Curfew hours are being extended beyond the current 2000 hours to 2200 hours for the convenience of those who are cleared late at ports of entry.”
 UPDATE: Zimbabwean curfew ran from 20:00 to 06:00. It has now been revised to be from 22:00 to 06:00.

description:
The secretary for the primary and secondary ministry in Zimbabwe announced that the government was ready for opening of schools as the government has taken relevant measures to protect learners from covid-19 through the supply of PPE to all provinces in the country.

 The secretary is quoted asserting that, “As for Monday , phase 1 of the opening of schools, we are prepared as government has provided the basic PPEs and are being delivered by NatPham to all the ten Provinces”.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The secretary for the primary and secondary ministry in Zimbabwe announced that the government was ready for opening of schools as the government has taken relevant measures to protect learners from covid-19 through the supply of PPE to all provinces in the country.

 The secretary is quoted asserting that, “As for Monday , phase 1 of the opening of schools, we are prepared as government has provided the basic PPEs and are being delivered by NatPham to all the ten Provinces”. 

In addition the minister of information has provided details on how the other students will resume classes. She is quoted as saying that,“In light of the high preparedness in the education sector schools will be reopened in a phased manner. Phase One for examination classes this will entail examination classes Grade Seven, Form Four and Form Six. Phase 2 will open on the 26th of October 2020 and would involve Grade Six, Form Three and Form Five. Finally Phase 3 will open on November 9 covering the rest of the learners including ECD-A, ECD-B, Grade One, Two, Three, Four, Five and then Form One and Two.” UPDATE: The previous policy only made provisions for the return of exam-writing student. This update gives detail on how other school going students will resume classes in stages.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Passengers arriving in Zimbabwe must produce a negative PCR result conducted within 48 hours prior to travel. Those showing symptoms of Covid-19 will be tested at the airport as sufficient testing equipment is in place,”

description: A Covid-19 Risk Allowance has been put into place from March 1 in Zimbabwe. The allowance will be paid to health workers and will vary based on their category risk factor. Workers with first hand contact to cases will receive ZWL$1,500 (US$38) per month, those with second hand contact will receive ZWL$900 (US$22.50) per month, and those with indirect or suspected contact will be eligible for ZWL600 (US$15, using black market exchange rates) per month.

description: The ministry of primary and secondary education of Zimbabwe has announced the resumption of contact lessons for students writing exams in 2020. Students that writing Cambridge exams will resumes lessons on 14 September 2020. Those who are writing Zimsec will resume classes on 28 September 2020.
type_text: The ministry of primary and secondary education announces resumption of contact classes for students sitting for exams in 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Zimbabwean minister of information and publicity announced the resumption of the issuing of work permits and visas for foreigners. This is an effort to lift restriction of external border travel.
type_text: The government is resuming the issuing of visas and permits to foreigners.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Zimbabwean minister of information and publicity announced the resumption of the issuing of work permits and visas for foreigners. This is an effort to lift restriction of external border travel.
 
Though airports are now open to receiving travelers, the Zimbabwean land borders remain closed to general human traffic. It is noted that, “Only commercial traffic, diplomats and returning residents are allowed passage across the land borders, Home Affairs and Cultural Heritage Minister Kazembe Kazembe confirmed yesterday, with the public health regulations put in place at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic still in place.”


 UPDATE: Despite the Zimbabwean airports being open to foreign travelers, the land borders remain closed to general human traffic.
type_text: The government is resuming the issuing of visas and permits to foreigners.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The minister of information and publicity in Zimbabwe announced the resumption of metered taxi services in Zimbabwe. Driving schools are also expected to resume services. These are efforts to ease and relax lockdown restrictions on public transport. This policy is aimed at public transports users in Zimbabwe.
type_text: The government relaxed public transport restrictions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The minister of Health in Zimbabwe has announced the launch of the covid-19 pandemic awareness. This awareness campaign is meant to enlighten Zimbabweans by providing them with accurate information on covid-19. This is meant to reduce covid-19 transmissions.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Any individual or group of individuals in Zimbabwe confirmed to be infected with Covid-19 must be quarantined for a period of up to 14 days, as of March 23. Quarantine must take place within their homes, in a hospital, or in another place of isolation.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Zimbabwe, it is a legal requirement that every returning resident be quarantined for 21 days, since the commencement of the initial lockdown on March 30.

target_geog_level: All countries

description: In Zimbabwe, it is a legal requirement that every returning resident be quarantined for 7 days, as announced on the 21st of April by Health Minister Obediah Moyo. After this period patients will be tested and the need for further isolation will be determined. UPDATE: The mandatory quarantine for returning residents was set at 21 days. It has now been reduced to 7 days.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
In Zimbabwe, it is a legal requirement that every returning resident be quarantined for 21 days, since the commencement of the initial lockdown on March 30. 

Update: as of 20 August it is noted that “Immigrants who test negative for COVID-19 upon arrival in the country will now no longer be required to go in quarantine as was previously the case, but will instead be put on home quarantine.” UPDATE: Immigrants who test negative for COVID-19 upon arrival in the country will now no longer be required to go in quarantine as was previously the case, but will instead be put on home quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: In Zimbabwe, it is a legal requirement that every returning resident be quarantined for 21 days, since the commencement of the initial lockdown on March 30. UPDATE: Returning citizens and residents will be ordered to quarantine for 14 days rather than the previous 7, as of August 20.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: It has been announced that “Arriving passengers without a COVID-19 test must either be tested upon arrival or quarantine in a government center for 14 days.  Diplomats are exempt from the testing requirement, but must still respect the 14-day home quarantine.  Borders remain open for cargo.”
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Zimbabwe, restriction of non-essential businesses has been extended from April 19th until May 3rd. As before, almost all businesses and markets must shut down, excluding essential services e.g. food markets, and funerals (limited to 50 mourners). In addition it was announced on that the mining industry will be allowed to scale up operations, and some operations in the manufacturing sector will be allowed to resume.

In Zimbabwe, restriction of non-essential businesses has been extended from May 3rd until May 17th. Small businesses and informal markets must remain shut (excluding essential services). Big companies will be allowed to reopen under supervision from 8am-3pm, and mandatory testing of all employees must take place before operations resume.

description: From the start of Zimbabwe's lockdown on March 30, only essential service providers are allowed to work.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Venues hosting low-risk sport competitions in Zimbabwe from May 17 may only open between the hours of 8am and 4:30pm. Low-risk sports include: archery, swimming, athletics, rowing, cycling, equestrian events, fencing, golf, gymnastics, motor sports/BMX, shooting, tennis, chess, darts, drafts or pool.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions atttached
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: As of May 22, Zimbabwe has implemented a reduction in working hours for nurses to limit exposure to Covid-19. Nurses will now work day shifts for 6 hours and night shifts for 12 hours, instead of the previous 8 hour shifts. They will also work only three days a week instead of five, with a four day break in between.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Regulated government working hours (e.g. work from home policies for government workers)

description: The Zimbabwean minister for health, who is also the vice president for the country, Dr Chiwenga has announced the cancellation of the scheduled By-elections. These elections have been cancelled as a public health precaution to  contain the risks of the spread of covid-19.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: A presidential amnesty was announced by the Zimbabwe government on March 2, allowing for the release of up to 6,000 prisoners to ease pressure on overcrowded jails. Amnesty will be given to prisoners convicted of non-violent crimes.
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)

description: In Zimbabwe, the Zimbabwe International Trade Fair (ZITF) that was to take place in the south-western city of Bulawayo from 21-25 April has been postponed, as announced on the 17th of March.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Zimbabwe, the 40th independence anniversary celebrations that were to take place in the south-western city of Bulawayo on the 18th of April have been postponed, as announced on the 17th of March.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On 23 March 2020, Ministry of Health and Child Care release a statement on CORONAVIRUS (COVID-19) update. According to that statement, President Cde. E.D Mnangagwa announced additional measures which take immediate effect. Those measures include - 1. Border control both inbound and outbound except for the movement of cargo. The government will close all borders to human traffic, excluding returning residents. 2. Ban on entertainment and recreational activities stating that government put a blanket ban. 3. All public gatherings should not exceed 50 persons. (religious fellowship, weddings, conferences, workshops and funerals. and 4. restriction on hospital visits; hospital visits have been reduced to one visit perday, invovling one relative per patient.

In Zimbabwe, restriction of non-essential businesses has been extended from May 3rd until May 17th. Small businesses and informal markets must remain shut (excluding essential services). Big companies will be allowed to reopen under supervision from 8am-3pm, and mandatory testing of all employees must take place before operations resume. UPDATE: In the start of the lockdown, the ZImbabwean government had imposed restrictions on operating hours of non-essential businesses. These businesses were meant to close for business at 16;30. However the government has allowed the increase in operating hours for business; they now close at 18:30 with immediate effect.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: The Zimbabwe minister of Information and publicity has announced the easing of restrictions on church gathering figures. Large numbers are still restricted the only allowed number now is 100.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
the original policy only permitted church gatherings to be 100. This revision of the the policy extends this figure to all other gatherings.  

the minister of information is quoted as saying "the Cabinet had agreed to set the maximum at 100, regardless of what the gathering was for. This was the maximum for some types of gathering, while others had been kept at a lower limit. Other existing public health regulations make it clear that public health regulations have to be followed at all gatherings, regardless of how many people attend". UPDATE: the original policy only allowed church gatherings to be not more than 100 but the new policy extends this number to other gatherings aswell.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The minister of health in Zimbabwe has announced that with effect from 03 January 2021 only 30 people are allowed  in a mass gathering. This policy will be in effect for 30 days starting from the day it was announced in 03 January 2021. UPDATE: The minister of health in Zimbabwe has announced the revised figures of people allowed in mass gatherings. He announced that as of 03 January only 30 people are allowed in a mass gathering such as churches and funerals. This should be in effect for 30 days.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
